articles.headline: Stocks Fall Back After Early Gains on Rescue Plan
articles.snippet: Shares ended lower as investors remained unsure that a plan to shore up the mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac would help the broader economy.
articles.abstract: Shares ended lower as investors remained unsure that a plan to shore up the mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac would help the broader economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shares ended lower Monday afternoon as investors remained unconvinced that Washington’s plan to shore up the mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac would help the broader economy.
articles.byline: By Abha Bhattarai and David Jolly

articles.headline: Court Clears eBay in Suit Over Sale of Counterfeit Goods
articles.snippet: Ruling against the jeweler Tiffany, a judge said that eBay does not have a legal responsibility to actively filter counterfeit items.
articles.abstract: Ruling against the jeweler Tiffany, a judge said that eBay does not have a legal responsibility to actively filter counterfeit items.
articles.lead_paragraph: EBay scored an important victory in an American court on Monday on how much vetting it is required to do of its auction listings, but the decision was in contrast to recent European court rulings.

articles.headline: Appointments With Red Ink
articles.snippet: A proposal to buck up Citigroup will do nothing to cushion blows that are likely to come in the days and weeks ahead, when it is is expected to report yet more grim quarterly results.
articles.abstract: A proposal to buck up Citigroup will do nothing to cushion blows that are likely to come in the days and weeks ahead, when it is is expected to report yet more grim quarterly results.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vikram S. Pandit summoned 60 executives to Armonk, N.Y., last Tuesday to present his plan to buck up Citigroup, the beleaguered bank he runs.

articles.headline: More Cuts Expected at General Motors
articles.snippet: The chief executive of G.M., Rick Wagoner, is set to announce further steps to cut costs amid slumping sales.
articles.abstract: The chief executive of G.M., Rick Wagoner, is set to announce further steps to cut costs amid slumping sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  General Motors is expected to reveal a “wide-ranging” plan on Tuesday to address its deteriorating sales and liquidity by cutting more jobs and taking other steps aimed at reviving its turnaround effort.
articles.byline: By Nick Bunkley and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: At the Uneasy Intersection of Bloggers and the Law
articles.snippet: There is no better way to get a blogger fired up than by telling him what he cannot publish -- although you might forgive a government prosecutor for thinking otherwise.
articles.abstract: There is no better way to get a blogger fired up than by telling him what he cannot publish -- although you might forgive a government prosecutor for thinking otherwise.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is no better way to get a blogger talking than by telling him what he cannot publish  although you might forgive a government prosecutor for thinking otherwise.

articles.headline: Want Obama in a Punch Line? First, Find a Joke
articles.snippet: Satirizing Barack Obama has not been easy for The New Yorker magazine or the phalanx of late-night TV hosts.
articles.abstract: Satirizing Barack Obama has not been easy for The New Yorker magazine or the phalanx of late-night TV hosts.
articles.lead_paragraph: What’s so funny about Barack Obama? Apparently not very much, at least not yet.

articles.headline: Arrest Is Sought of Sudan Leader in Genocide Case
articles.snippet: The International Criminal Court formally requested the arrest of President Omar Hassan al-Bashir on Monday.
articles.abstract: The International Criminal Court formally requested the arrest of President Omar Hassan al-Bashir on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  The prosecutor at the International Criminal Court formally requested an arrest warrant on Monday for Sudan’s president, Omar Hassan al-Bashir, on charges of genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity committed during the past five years of bloodshed in the Darfur region of his country.
articles.byline: By Marlise Simons, Lydia Polgreen and Jeffrey Gettleman

articles.headline: Confidence Ebbs for Bank Sector and Stocks Fall
articles.snippet: Even as the Bush administration moved to rescue the two largest mortgage finance companies, confidence in the banking sector sank.
articles.abstract: Even as the Bush administration moved to rescue the two largest mortgage finance companies, confidence in the banking sector sank.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as the Bush administration moved to rescue the nation’s two largest mortgage finance companies, confidence in the banking sector spiraled downward Monday.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Places Captured in Time, but Not Frozen There
articles.snippet: Retracing the routes of guides conceived as part of a 1930s jobs program reveals how much the nation has changed.
articles.abstract: Retracing the routes of guides conceived as part of a 1930s jobs program reveals how much the nation has changed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WINTHROP, Wash. — They were still wearing Stetsons and spurs, not the tight cycling shorts you see these days, when a writer dispatched by the federal government during the Great Depression reached the end of the road here in the North Cascades.

articles.headline: Scramble Led to Rescue Plan on Mortgages
articles.snippet: The rescue of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac was hastily arranged after bankers said further erosion of confidence could have a cascading effect.
articles.abstract: The rescue of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac was hastily arranged after bankers said further erosion of confidence could have a cascading effect.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration hastily arranged the dramatic Sunday evening rescue of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac after Wall Street executives and foreign central bankers told Washington that any further erosion of confidence could have a cascading effect around the world, officials said on Monday.

articles.headline: In ’06 Bomb Plot Trial, a Question of Imminence
articles.snippet: Testimony has shown little evidence that the defendants were prepared to strike quickly or of any link to Al Qaeda.
articles.abstract: Testimony has shown little evidence that the defendants were prepared to strike quickly or of any link to Al Qaeda.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  When Scotland Yard disrupted what it called a plot to blow up trans-Atlantic airliners with liquid explosives in August 2006, officials in Britain and the United States said the deadliest terrorist attack since Sept. 11 had been averted.

articles.headline: From the Inside, Jerry Yang Looks Out for Yahoo
articles.snippet: At a mogul retreat, there was sympathy for Yahoo’s founder and new questions about Microsoft’s judgment.
articles.abstract: At a mogul retreat, there was sympathy for Yahoo’s founder and new questions about Microsoft’s judgment.
